article_title: Broomfield City Council set to adopt 2015 budget on Tuesday
article_text:
View the proposed budget To view Broomfield's proposed 2015 budgets, visit broomfield.org and click on "Finance."

City Council on Tuesday is expected to approve the budgets for the coming year

Council is slated to vote on the 2015 proposed budgets for the city and county, the Housing Authority, the Urban Renewal Authority and the Arista Local Improvement District.

Residents can view the proposed budgets online, and will have one last chance to speak about the proposed budgets just before the vote.

The proposed 2015 budget calls for money to add jobs, renovate buildings and plan for long-term resources that will serve an expanding population as the city's housing inventory continues to grow.

With growth comes spending to maintain resources and build new ones, said Broomfield finance director Pat Soderberg.

The budget calls for spending on big-ticket projects, such as construction of a new $16.5 million Health and Human Services building, which will offer expanded space for programs.

Another big-ticket project is continuing construction on the 120th Avenue Connection, which will connect Colo. 128 and 120th Avenue, creating an easier route from U.S. 36 and Wadsworth Parkway to 120th Avenue. The project is meant to ease traffic woes.

Advertisement

The 2015 budget includes $10.6 million for the road project. The first phases were completed in fall 2010. Broomfield will have to spend about $1.4 million more than originally thought to start the next phase of the project. The project came in about $2.8 million over budget, and Broomfield likely will split the extra cost with the Colorado Department of Transportation, said Deputy City and County Manager Kevin Standbridge.

The proposed budget also includes several projects requested by or supported by residents, including a field expansion at Broomfield County Commons. The budget calls for $3.69 million to construct a new athletic field area, dubbed the "yellow pod."

That funding covers the athletic field improvements, but doesn't cover adding more parking, Soderberg said.

Parking for the future field is in front of the current dog park, she said.

Residents sent in numerous letters supporting a plan to build the field, including parents who wanted their children to have a field where they could play lacrosse.

Residents can still comment at Tuesday's meeting, and comments will be logged for next year's budget process.

Soderberg said the public had several chances to give suggestions or feedback on the proposed budget, either at council meetings or via email.

During the 2015 budget process, most residents who commented did so via email, and the majority asked for funding to put in more turf fields at Broomfield County Commons.

"There was a lot of interest in that," Soderberg said.

Other recreation projects are in the works for 2015, including repairs and upgrades to the Broomfield Community Center locker rooms, according to the budget report.

Smaller maintenance projects also are in the 2015 budget, such as fixing 35 miles of roads and replacing 5,000 feet of water mains.

The budget also calls for adding hours to several existing jobs and creating a few new jobs.

Broomfield will add the equivalent of 8.45 full-time positions in 2015 to make up for 26 positions cut or unfilled during the recession, according to the budget report.

Those positions include an additional police patrol officer, an additional engineering construction inspector and more staff in the Community Development Department, because of Broomfield's growing multi-family housing developments, the report states.

The budget also includes $306,000 to provide health insurance coverage to 38 part-time employees who work about 30 hours a week.

The new health care costs are part of Affordable Care Act requirements, Soderberg said.

The budget also includes $85,000 to replace 200 smaller, sickly ash trees to help ward off the emerald ash borer, an insect that has killed ash trees across the country.

The emerald ash borer is not in Broomfield right now, but is expected to start infecting trees in the city in one to three years, according to the capital improvement budget.
